inlineContent.text: Materials define the appearance of 3D models in RealityKit, by defining how their surfaces interact with light. Materials can also occlude objects behind them, hold shaders, or act as portals to view other worlds with
RealityKit includes a few material types to help you get started, including
for basic color and textures, and
for realistic lighting effects such as reflections, roughness, and emission.

abstract.text: Apply textures to the surface of your scene’s 3D objects to give each object a unique appearance.
An object that defines the transparency options for a custom material.
An object that defines the ambient occlusion of an entity’s surface.
An alias for the cull mode object that’s appropriate for this material class.
Use windows, volumes, and immersive spaces to teach people about the Earth.
An object that defines the color of an entity’s sheen.
An object that defines the intensity of an entity’s clear, shiny
coating.
An alias for the cull mode object that’s appropriate for this material class.
Use attachments to place 2D content relative to 3D content in your visionOS app.

abstract.text: An alias for the texture coordinate transform that’s appropriate for this material class.
An object that defines the color of the light an entity emits.
A type that describes the material aspects of a mesh, like color and
texture.
A set of types that material parameters can use.
Build a RealityKit component to support standard visionOS gestures on any entity.
The scalar parameter applied to a material.

A component that allows entities to cross portal boundaries.

objects.

abstract.text: An alias for the cull mode object that’s appropriate for this material class.

abstract.text: An object that defines the roughness of an entity’s surface.

abstract.text: Write Metal shader functions to implement custom rendering effects.
